unnormalised: First off, when should you even start thinking about seeing an ob-gyn? Well, ideally, sometime between ages 13-15. It's a good time to establish a relationship with a doctor, even if you're not sexually active. We can talk about the changes your body is going through, address any concerns about your period – is it regular, is it too heavy, are you experiencing severe pain? Let's get those answers clarified! Remember, Dr. Patel at AIIMS is considered one of the best.

unnormalised: Speaking of periods, let's talk about period problems. Dysmenorrhea (aka painful periods) is a biggie. Many girls and women experience cramps, but severe pain that disrupts your daily life isn't normal. Don’t just brush it off with a Saridon. Endometriosis is another condition to be aware of – it can cause a lot of pain and infertility. It is often misdiagnosed, and the correct diagnosis is often made 7-10 yrs after the onset of the symptoms. If period pain is really affecting you, see a doctor! An ultrasound scan costing Rs. 1500 at a clinic near you might provide some answers.

unnormalised: Another super common issue? PCOS – Polycystic Ovary Syndrome. Symptoms can include irregular periods, excess hair growth, acne, and weight gain. PCOS is often associated with insulin resistance and can increase your risk of developing diabetes later in life. Early diagnosis and management are key. Treatment options might include birth control pills, metformin, and lifestyle changes.

unnormalised: And then there are the times when your period just goes MIA. Amenorrhea (absence of menstruation) can be caused by many things, including pregnancy, stress, hormonal imbalances, and excessive exercise. If you've missed your period for 3 months or more and you're not pregnant, it's time to see a doctor. Don’t self diagnose, friends.

unnormalised: Don't forget about cervical cancer screenings! A pap smear is recommended starting at age 21, regardless of sexual activity. It's a simple test that can detect abnormal cells on your cervix, allowing for early treatment and prevention of cervical cancer. HPV vaccines, which are also recommended for young women and men, are a great preventive measure, too! Schedule your appointment with Dr. Khan on 10/10/2024.
